resources.string: The Black Eagle Complex is probably the most monumental architectural accomplishment in Oradea and in Transylvania, as far as the Secession building style is concerned. The contest to build this architectural complex was won by architects Komor Marcell and Jakab Dezső. Its construction, on the old location of the “Black Eagle” Inn, begins in 1907, under the supervision of construction engineer Sztarill Ferenc, and in December 1908, the edification is complete.

Ever since its beginnings, Oradea Fortress was the polarizing nucleus for the settlements of the area, by concentrating the political, military, administrative, judicial and religious functions within its walls. It constituted an important religious center after the canonization, in 1192, of the founder of the Oradea diocese as Saint Ladislaus the Thaumaturge, becoming during the 13th and 14th Centuries a pilgrimage spot on par with any other in Europe. The active involvement of the bishops in its development and its effervescent cultural life transformed the Oradea Fortress of the 15th Century in one of the most important centers of Humanism and the Renaissance in Central-Eastern Europe.

The Neolog Synagogue Zion is situated across from 1 Decembrie Square, on Independenţei Street. It was built after the division of the Jewish community of Oradea into Orthodox Jews and Neolog or Congress Jews, and in 1878 it was finally standing in the town of Oradea. This spectacular Eclectic building was erected after the plan of Busch David and Rimanóczy Kálmán-Sr. Similar to the other synagogue, the exterior and interior adornments are Moorish. The main differences between the two Mosaic temples lie in the monumentality of the latter. Unlike the Orthodox Synagogue, the Neolog temple stands out through massiveness, monumentality, and, last but not least, ideal location.

Sztarill Palace (now Hotel Astoria) with the renowned EMKE coffee-shop – where the poet Ady Endre undertook much of his literary activity, and where he met his inspiring muse, Leda – still exists, under the name Astoria. This establishment was built at the intersection of the current Teatrului Street with Ferdinand Square. The palace was designed by Sztarill Ferenc, between the years 1902 and 1906, in eclectic style with obvious Secession influences. The building is evidence of the architectural good taste, but also for the ornamental and chromatic exuberance which fascinated local architects and Oradea citizens alike. Rehabilitated a few years ago, the Sztarill Palace showcases its striking carousel of curved lines and colors.

Built in the 1950s under the name \'August 23rd Park\', it represents an oasis of greenery in the middle of the city. Subjected to the canons of modernity, the park was re-done with numerous refined landscaping arrangements. It also houses \'Casa de Cultura a Sindicatelor\', a Cultural Centre which regularly hosts a wide range of shows and events.
December 1st Park, Piaţa 1 Decembrie, Oradea, Romania

A 3-hour walk delight, the Cris River Meadow follows the route of the main river that passes through the city from east to west. Tha maximum amplitude of vegetation development is in the eastern area of the city, where the quiet is conspicuous and the explosion of green extends to the summit of the hills in the area. The dominant vegetation is lover of water both in the area of wooden vegetation as well as the herbaceous layer.

Situated in the southwest part of Oradea, the local Zoo hosts over 650 animals from nearly all continents, with species like: monkeys, bears, wolves, tigers, jaguars, deer, pythons, and fawns. The majority are pairs that reproduce naturally, in their own habitats. The Oradea Zoo spreads over 75,000 square metres and is an ideal space for relaxation and immersion into nature. Typical opening times are 9am-6pm.

Delicious mix of Mediterranean and Romanian food, served in a cosy, laid-back ambiance. In summer, you can relish a delicious lemonade on their spacey terrace right next to the Cris river while enjoying the beautiful views.
An Italian restaurant for the seafood lover, Corsarul offers marvellous pasta, risotto, pizzas, as well as delicious beef, pork, chicken, and fish dishes.
Well-situated coffee shop with a cozy atmosphere, wide selection of drinks, and tasty sandwiches. Regarded by many as the \'best coffee in town\'.

Dominating Ferdinand Square with its imposing column facade, Oradea\'s State Theatre building houses Queen Mary Theatre (\'Teatrul Regina Maria\'), which regularly runs shows in its 650-seat main hall. With very affordable prices and plays running every day, it represents a \'must see\' for all theatre lovers.

Promoted as the largest aquapark in Eastern Europe, Nymphaea offers 10 slides, 15 pools, 6 saunas, massage salons, restaurants, and sports facilities. The aquatic park features both indoor and outdoor facilities, with the latter open from 1 May to 30 September. Typical opening hours are 10am to 10pm.
Aleea Ştrandului 13 B Oradea, Oradea 410051, Romania
